writingDetail.html:
Luis, you and I have been talking, and we wanted to revisit it here as well, about within a format how a different card can have different impacts on different archetypes. But Matt's question zooms us out one step to the format level and how similar cards can go from being just fine to being amazing. What do you make of that?

Yeah, there are definitely context differences that, of course, will impact this dramatically. There are some cards that are pretty much good every format. Scorching Dragonfire might be better here than in most because there are so many enduring things you need to exile or death triggers. But the 2 mana instant deal 3 with minor upside or even no upside has just always been one of the top red commons every format it's ever been in. It goes up and down a little bit, but not by much. That said, there's a lot of cards that someone can be great in a format and some can only be mediocre. And I think the speed of the format, what the stat lines are of the common creatures,

whether the format is a lot of removal or a small amount of removal, all that stuff goes together. And also what color is good. I would generally say 2 mana white for a 2/1 flyer draw card is going to be better than 2/1 flyer draw card because white is just going to use that body better. White is going to be more aggressive. White is going to care about having an aggressive flyer more often. How good would Piranha Fly in this format be if it was red or if it was white? It would be awesome. In blue, sometimes it's good, but it's often not. And that's kind of where you look at similar cards and why there's probably pretty different amounts of impact they have.

What do you think, Paul? Yeah, I mean, it just makes a lot of sense. One of the big things for me is, I guess, creature sizing. And after you play with the set for a couple of weeks, you start to realize what toughness and what power are relevant in this format. For example, in Dustmourne, there's a bunch of 2/2s running around, right? Because you have a bunch of manifest. So in that instance, shock effects go up in value, whereas in other sets where people are just kind of playing 3 mana 3/3s and 3 mana 3/4s, shock becomes a card you play, but you're not as excited to play.

So sizing, I think that's a big level up moment for me in any set. Once I start realizing, oh, man, like if I play four toughness creatures and everything else is a three power creature, then I know people are undervaluing this card. Whereas I'm going to take this card and it's going to have a much better impact on the board just because of the sizing of the creatures. Yeah, it's also cool. I mean, it's good job security for us, right? Because the fact that you can, like we could read Organ Hoarder and go, yeah, this looks pretty solid, C+, whatever, you know, and because that's kind of the context that we have during a set review and have it be end up being the best common in the set,

you know, significant bump up means that it is still hard to predict these things. We don't get a cheat code that just tells us this is going to be good. And now they tend to maybe even give you a little bit of onboard presence and something like that. but not just kind of wasting mana. And as the game became more efficient, as the average creature got better, as the average card got better, it limited those type of cards went down because it was like, well, you're just always drawing gas anyway, you don't really need to like search for something specific. But then once they kicked in a little something, you know, just a little old one that you can make mana with or, you know, a food token or something, it was like, oh, now these are right back near the top.

It makes these things difficult to predict. And I mean, that's, of course, you know, why we're here is to is to predict these things. That's a really good question, Matt. Thanks for that.
